title: Reliability of a Small Supplier
vignette: You buy goods from a small independent vendor who lacks formal certification. Is it acceptable to rely on them without more checks?

options.text: Use/consume; assume most small producers adhere to ethical standards nowadays.
Verify compliance before using/consuming; uncertainty requires caution.

title: Distributing Unverified Donations
vignette: A charity gets packaged food with no allergen or sourcing details. Should volunteers hand it out without further verification?

options.text: Distribute as-is; leniency for those in urgent need.
Must verify or procure compliant goods first, even if it means less aid.

title: Accepting a Host's Claims about Ingredients
vignette: At a meal, your host assures you that everything served meets high standards, but packaging you saw suggests otherwise. Do you eat to preserve harmony?

options.text: Trust the host; social peace is more important than your doubts.
Decline politely or discretely avoid the questionable items; adherence to your standards comes first.

title: Unasked Quality Checks on a Friend's Goods
vignette: A friend stored goods at your facility. You suspect they were never properly checked. Is it okay to arrange tests without first asking them?

options.text: Yes; it's a presumed benefit and protects them from potential issues.
No; it's their property and responsibility—requires their explicit consent.

title: Insufficient Sample for Testing
vignette: You only have a small batch of components, not enough for complete quality tests. Should you do partial checks or wait for more?

options.text: Perform what checks are possible; partial compliance is better than none.
Do not use until a sufficient quantity for full testing is available.

title: Liability for Incorrect Product Labels
vignette: A vendor sold devices advertised as energy efficient. Later, one device proves otherwise. Should all sales from that batch be compensated?

options.text: Yes; buyers rely on the seller’s representation—vendor should compensate or rectify for all affected sales.
No; presume it was an isolated error—only that specific device or batch is suspect, pending investigation.

title: Mixing Certified and Unverified Goods
vignette: Certified coffee beans accidentally mix with beans of unknown origin. Does the entire mix require re-certification, or can it be labelled accordingly?

options.text: Yes; uncertainty affects the entire batch.
Attempt to sample and certify proportionally if possible, or sell as 'mixed source' to avoid waste, with clear labeling.

title: Cooking with Questionable Ingredients
vignette: After preparing a large stew, you learn a key ingredient may have been misrepresented. Do you serve it with a disclaimer or discard it entirely?

options.text: Serve after attempting to verify the source or clearly label the uncertainty.
Discard the entire batch; the cooking process doesn't resolve the sourcing doubt and reputation is key.

title: Buying Snacks When Checking Is Hard
vignette: While traveling by train, snack vendors walk through the cars but you can't verify their goods. Should you eat now or wait for a station with trusted options?

options.text: Eat; leniency applies due to the circumstances and immediate need.
Wait and verify/buy known items at a station or destination.

title: Imported Goods and Local Rules
vignette: You source electronic parts from abroad. The supplier claims they meet international standards, but local laws are strict. Can you rely on the claim without further proof?

options.text: Exempt if supplier provides credible claim of adherence to equivalent international standards.
Treat as 'uncertain compliance' until independently verified against local regulations.
